Many funds reversed lower along with the broader market, but these two U.S. index ETFs managed to hold gains.Blue chips and small-cap stocks closed Friday with modest advances as tracked by the Dow Jones industrial average and the Russell 2000 index.IShares Russell 2000 (IWM) broke out intraday past a 141.92 flat-base buy point to mark a new high. But it pared its gain to 0.5%, closing just below the entry. It's formed a series of three bases almost right next to each other since December. Before that, IWM rose 10% from a flat-base breakout in November.The fund, launched in May 2000, has attracted $36.6 billion in assets. IWM has lagged the S&P 500 this year through June 8 with a 4.8% gain vs. the benchmark index's 9.7%, according to Morningstar Inc. But its one-year return of 20.8% has outpaced the S&P 500's 17.3%, and the ETF's 15-year average annual return of 9.07% is also ahead at 9.07% vs. 8.11%.Since May 19, IWM's 4% gain has doubled iShares S&P 500's (IVV) gain.Several of the tech names in IWM's top holdings took a beating Friday, including Advanced Micro Devices (AMD), Take-Two Interactive Software (TTWO) and Coherent (COHR), which fell about 5% each. But its financial names helped offset some of the losses.SPDR S&P MidCap 400 (MDY) pared its gain to 0.3% Friday to close slightly below a 320.58 flat-base buy point. It had cleared the entry earlier in the session. The ETF started forming the current pattern after a 3% advance from a prior flat base and 7% from the one before.It's up nearly 6% year to date through June 8 and has slightly underperformed the S&P 500 for one-, three- and five-year average annual returns. But it's ahead of the benchmark index for the 10- and 15-year periods with respective returns of 8.2% and 9.8% vs. 7.2% and 8.2% for the S&P 500.The $18.8 billion fund, which was launched in May 1995, counts Everest Re Group (RE), Align Technology (ALGN) and Duke Realty (DRE) among its top holdings. Real estate investment trusts and other financials turned in a solid performance Friday.Moving over to Thursday's ETF picks, the featured pair of gold funds have pulled back from their cup-with-handle buy points as gold prices slid for a third straight session. Apple (AAPL) is looking to differentiate Apple Music from other streaming music services, most notably Spotify, by adding more original, exclusive video content.Apple already has secured the rights to "Carpool Karaoke" and concert videos and is working on a show featuring hip-hop legend Dr. Dre. But now it wants to ramp up its production of music programming significantly and is in talks with Hollywood studios to make that happen, the Wall Street Journal reported Thursday.Apple executives have told people in Hollywood that they hope to start offering original scripted TV shows for Apple Music by the end of 2017, the WSJ reported.Apple wants to offer shows that are comparable to critically acclaimed programs like "Stranger Things" on Netflix (NFLX) and "Westworld" on Time Warner's (TWX) HBO, the report said.IBD'S TAKE: Apple stock broke out of a cup-with-handle chart pattern on Monday, clearing a buy point of 118.12. It had been building the pattern over the past 11 weeks.Apple stock slipped 0.42% to 119.25 on the stock market today.Apple has flirted with the idea of offering a streaming video service for years, including a possible "skinny bundle" featuring a "best of cable" channel package. But Apple has been unsuccessful in securing content deals.Offering a robust package of video content on Apple Music could give the company confidence to pursue its own over-the-top internet video network.Apple Music costs $9.99 a month for an individual membership and $14.99 a month for family membership, which gives up to six people access to the service. Apple also offers a student membership rate of $4.99 a month for college students. To get users hooked, Apple offers a three-month free trial.In December, Apple said it had more than 20 million subscribers to Apple Music. Spotify reported having over 40 million subscribers in September. Privately held Spotify is considering an IPO for this year.RELATED:Apple AirPods Wireless Earbuds Off To Fast StartApple Looks To Augment Product Lineup With AR Smartglasses

Apple (AAPL) stock rose on Thursday as investors continued to weigh prospects for the company's iPhone 7 and other opportunities.Apple climbed 2% to 98.79 on the stock market today. Shares of the Cupertino, Calif.-based company have now risen in six of the past seven trading sessions.The down day was Wednesday, when Apple stock fell a fraction after research firm Kantar Worldpanel released data showing that Samsung is outselling Apple in U.S. smartphone sales. In the three months ending in May, Samsung accounted for 37% of all U.S. smartphone sales, with Apple at 29%.Looking just at their flagship models, Samsung held a narrower lead. Samsung's Galaxy S7 series accounted for 16% of sales in the March-May period, while the iPhone 6S series accounted for 14.6%.IBD'S TAKE: Apple stock has been above its 50-day moving average line since July 7. It and two other big-name tech firms are testing key support levels. For more details, read Alissa Williams' in-depth analysis.Of course, the Galaxy S7 launched in March, taking advantage of a natural lull in the annual iPhone release schedule. Apple is expected to release its 10th-generation handset, the iPhone 7, in September.Apple does a better job of holding on to its customers, Kantar said. Just 5% of Samsung smartphone purchases in the U.S. in the March-May period came from those switching from Apple, while 14% of Apple purchases came from those switching from Samsung.Meanwhile, Apple this week seemed to throw cold water on speculation about its intentions in video streaming.In an interview with the Hollywood Reporter, Eddy Cue, Apple's senior vice president of internet software and services, said the company's experiments with original video production are projects designed to support current businesses."We are only going into the content business (with projects) that we think are really tied to our products," Cue said. "Right now, that's Apple Music."That includes a Taylor Swift tour documentary for Apple Music subscribers. Apple also reportedly is producing a scripted drama from Apple employee and hip-hop icon Dr. Dre. Plus, Apple is making a reality TV show about software development called "Planet of the Apps."Cue dismissed the idea of Apple producing a traditional TV show."We're not in the business of trying to create TV shows," he said. "If we see it being complementary to the things we're doing at Apple Music or if we see it being something that's innovative on our platform, we may help them and guide them and make suggestions. But we're not trying to compete with Netflix (NFLX) or compete with Comcast (CMCSA)."

Apple (AAPL) reportedly is looking to buy Tidal, a streaming music service run by rap mogul Jay Z, to add more exclusive content for its own service, Apple Music.Tidal has strong ties to popular artists such as Kanye West, Rihanna, Madonna and Jay Z's wife, Beyonce. Tidal has 4.2 million paying subscribers, compared with 15 million for Apple Music and 30 million for industry leader Spotify.The Wall Street Journal reported the talks between Apple and Tidal late Thursday. It described the discussions as preliminary and cautioned that they might not result in a deal.New York Times music journalist Ben Sisario tweeted late Thursday that his sources told him that Apple has no intention of buying Tidal. The rumor might have been started to increase Tidal's perceived value, Forbes contributor Bobby Owsinski said in a post Friday.Samsung earlier this year was in talks to buy Tidal, but those negotiations felt through.Jay Z bought Tidal in March 2015 for $56 million from Swedish company Aspiro. He gave 16 famous artists and bands small stakes in the service in exchange for exclusive music releases.But Tidal has been rocked by management turmoil, churning through three CEOs in less than a year, the WSJ reported.Tidal charges $9.99 a month to stream its 40 million-song catalog or $19.99 a month for a high-fidelity version.Apple charges $9.99 a month for Apple Music for individuals. It also offers a six-person family plan for $14.99 a month.Apple Music was based on the streaming service Beats Music, which Apple acquired in its $3 billion purchase of headphone maker Beats Electronics in August 2014. As part of the deal, Apple gained the services of rap star Dr. Dre and music mogul Jimmy Iovine.The top music streaming services lately have been focused on exclusives to attract subscribers.Tidal is the only service offering the music catalog of late pop star Prince. It also was the first to stream Kanye's new album "Life Of Pablo" and Beyonce's latest "Lemonade."Apple had an exclusive on Drake's latest album "Views" and a concert film featuring Taylor Swift.Piper Jaffray analyst Gene Munster said an Apple Music-Tidal combination could make sense at the right price."Jay Z purchased the service in March of 2015 for $56 million, and since then has added significantly to the quality of the services," Munster said. "Our best guess is the deal price would be below $500 million."Services like Apple Music are an important focus for Apple as it seeks to further monetize its user base, Munster said.Meanwhile, Spotify this week accused Apple of anticompetitive behavior for rejecting the latest version of its iOS app. Apple said the new Spotify app violated the App Store's "business model rules" by encouraging consumers to bypass Apple's billing system.Spotify said Apple's mandate to take a 30% cut of subscription revenue puts third-party apps at a competitive disadvantage to Apple's own services, such as Apple Music.Apple responded to Spotify's June 26 allegations on Friday, BuzzFeed reported.In a letter sent to Spotify general counsel Horacio Gutierrez, Apple general counsel Bruce Sewell said Spotify was seeking preferential treatment."We find it troubling that you are asking for exemptions to the rules we apply to all developers and are publicly resorting to rumors and half-truths about our service," Sewell wrote.Apple stock was up a fraction, near 96, in late-afternoon trading in the stock market today.

Apple's (AAPL) smartwatch, the Apple Watch, is once again the most talked-about product of the 2015 holiday shopping season, according to IBM Watson Trend.Apple Watch was the top trending product when IBM (IBM) debuted its IBM Watson Trend App for the holiday shopping season on Nov. 18.But Samsung TVs surpassed it during the Black Friday sales weekend as consumers buzzed about low-cost 4K ultrahigh-definition television deals.The IBM Watson Trend App analyzes millions of conversations across social networks, blogs, forums, comments, ratings and reviews to determine which products are likely to be top gifts this holiday season. It scours the Internet for conversations related to purchase decisions and tries to understand the context, meaning and sentiment or tone of the comments.The goal of the IBM Watson Trend App is to identify the hot-selling products of the holiday season. But judging from the sample comments IBM posted about the Apple Watch, it seems to be picking up some excitement about the second-generation Apple Watch, not the current model on sale."Battery life, while OK on the Apple Watch, could be improved to last several days at a minimum," one commenter said."All Apple needs to do is to make a round Apple watch," another said.IBM Watson Trend now gives the Apple Watch a top score of 100, even though it admitted that there are complaints about battery life and people waiting for the second-generation model to go on sale next year before buying.Last week, Apple Watch slipped to second place with a score of 72 while Samsung TVs climbed to first place with a score of 100. This week, with Apple at 100, Samsung TVs are in second place with a score of 96.Other products in the top 10 on IBM Watson Trend on Monday included Sony (SNE) TVs, LG TVs, Nikon cameras, "Star Wars" Legos, Canon cameras, Apple Beats by Dre headphones, Sony cameras and Vizio TVs.RELATED:Apple Watch closing in on Fitbit for wearables lead.Apple Watch fans skew male and gay, report says.

Do you have some mad money that's looking for a place to work in the stock market? Consider some REITs, which have boosted dividends this year. Likewise, consider sector mutual funds or ETFs that hold them.Why mad money? Because REITs still carry a risk of price declines if investors rotate out of them into higher-paying bonds if the Federal Reserve raises interest rates or the investors anticipate a rate hike.And real estate sector mutual funds as a group have lagged the S&P 500 so far this year through Nov. 5.Still, if you can wait out the storm — assuming that the storm actually passes — dividends paid by several have grown.And that trend might continue, writes Todd Rosenbluth, director of ETF & mutual fund research for both S&P Capital IQ and SNL Financial.That makes them attractive to income-hungry investors."Recent research from SNL Financial reveals that REITs are hiking dividends at a rapid clip," Rosenbluth wrote in a report on Monday.One hundred and one, or 45%, of U.S. publicly traded REITs and property companies tracked by SNL real estate analyst Chris Hudgins have raised dividends at least once in the first 10 months of 2015, Rosenbluth reported.That was a faster pace than in prior years. The 101 REITs outnumber the 88 and 92 that increased dividends in the same periods of, respectively, 2013 and 2014, Hudgins' research says.Rosenbluth added: "This is a pleasant surprise for many investors. The case against REITs is that their relatively high dividend yields (for stocks) will be less appealing as the yield on the 10-year Treasury moves higher as the Federal Reserve prepares to initiate a rate-hike sequence. Yet as Hudgins notes, 12 U.S. REITs and property companies raised their dividends in October, up from seven in September."S&P Capital IQ likes three of the REITs, based on fundamentals.Here's what Rosenbluth wrote about each, with some updated yield figures: Simon Property Group (SPG) raised its quarterly dividend in late October by 3.2% to $1.60. Simon raised its dividend during all four quarters of 2015, and its annual dividend of $6.40 is 56% higher than it was three years ago.Simon has a 3.1% dividend yield. Crown Castle (CCI) increased its quarterly dividend 7.9% in October, which elevated the wireless-focused specialized REIT's dividend yield to 4.2%, higher than its peers' 3.9%."CCI began paying dividends in February 2014 as it converted to a REIT, but in 18 months its quarterly dividend has nearly tripled to $0.89 per share," Rosenbluth wrote. Duke Realty (DRE), a diversified REIT, raised its dividend 5.9% in October.REIT HoldingsRosenbluth also noted that Duke, Simon and Crown were among the top 25 holdings for iShares U.S. Real Estate ETF (IYR) at the end of October. The ETF has $4.6 billion in assets spread across specialized REITs (24% of assets), retail REITs (20%), residential REITs (15%), office REITs (11%), and others. IYR has a 3.7% yield and a 0.43% expense ratio.Vanguard REIT ETF (VNQ) — the largest REIT ETF, with $26 billion in assets — has large stakes in Simon and Duke. "It has more exposure to retail and residential REITs but less exposure to specialized REITs," Rosenbluth wrote. "It has an 0.12% expense ratio and a 3.9% yield."Some mutual funds have exposure to those REITs as well.The $51.5 billion Vanguard REIT Index Fund has the same holdings as VNQ.Simon Property and Duke Realty are top-10 holdings of $4.5 billion Fidelity Real Estate Investment Portfolio .All three REITs took price hits last week. Simon and Crown fell after Fed Chair Janet Yellen said that a rate hike in December is possible. Duke fell on Friday.S&P Capital IQ thinks the three are still good to buy and own based on fundamentals, attractively low valuations and appealing dividends."Yes, those REITS were negatively impacted by (the) likelihood of higher rates and actions by the Fed," Rosenbluth told IBD. "(But all) of them are buy recommends. No changes made, but there is more upside than before."Follow Paul Katzeff on Twitter: @IBD_PKatzeff.

The Apple Watch is hot. So are Nike running shoes, Samsung TVs and Activision Blizzard's (ATVI) "Call of Duty" video game. So sayeth the IBM (IBM) Watson Trend app, which uses its "understanding of natural language and machine learning technologies" to sort through 10,000 online sources — Facebook (FB), Twitter (TWTR), blogs, forums, reviews, etc. — to predict which products will be hot this holiday season.

Each item's trend score is graded on a curve, says IBM, with the top trend of the day receiving a mark of 100. The app, which sorts products into tech, toys and health categories, also displays the preceding three months' worth of scores and forecasts the upcoming three weeks' scores for each trend.

As of Nov. 18, the Apple (AAPL) Watch has held onto its 100-point score, with little apparent deviation from the No. 1 spot over the last few months. And it wasn't the only Apple product to make the list, which shouldn't be a surprise even to those lacking a supercomputer with artificial intelligence.

A trend listed as "Apple iMac Computers" nabbed a score of 21 as the iPad Pro and 27" Retina iMac spurred online talk, while Apple-owned Beats by Dre came in at 22, having tumbled from August's low-80s rating.

The iPhone 6S owns a spot on Watson's list — but with a meager score of 4. Earlier in November, Apple chip supplier stocks fell on reports that the iPhone maker had trimmed its orders for the month by 10% on dwindling demand in Asia.

Overall, tech gadgets have a strong presence on the hot list, including TVs from Samsung (with a score of 53), Sony (SNE) (32) and LG (23), as well as professional-grade cameras from Canon (30) and Nikon (23). Online chatter also brought up wearables such as Facebook-owned Oculus Rift virtual-reality gear (1).
Nike (NKE) running shoes top the health category, followed by Vilano bikes.
In the toy category, Legos are proving to be hot, with various iterations of the classic block-building set high in the rankings, including Lego City, Lego Friends and Minecraft Legos.

And as the Dec. 18 release of "Star Wars: Episode VII — The Force Awakens" approaches, fans of the Walt Disney (DIS) -owned Lucasfilm franchise are getting pumped with talk of the R2-D2 Astromech Interactive Droid and Star Wars Legos.

"The new Star Wars movie, 'The Force Awakens,' has helped make Lego Bricks the 'it' toy of the 2015 holiday season, and it's likely that many will sell out, including the new Millennium Falcon set," said IBM in a press release Wednesday.

Stereo headphones from Apple (AAPL) and its subsidiary Beats Electronics drown out the competition when it comes to U.S. teen consumers.

Piper Jaffray's semiannual survey of U.S. teenagers found that Beats by Dr. Dre is the No. 1 brand of headphones. Asked which brand of headphones they planned to buy next, 44.2% of teens said they planned to get Beats, up from 41.9% in the spring and 43.7% in fall 2014. Apple ranked second with 31.7%, up from 31.2% in the spring and 29.8% last fall.
Taken together, Apple's two headphone brands grabbed 75.9% of teen purchase intent in the latest survey.

Coming in a distant third is Skullcandy (SKUL) with 8.9% of teen purchase intent. The percentage of teens planning to buy Skullcandy headphones has been relatively stable, down from 9.4% in the spring but up from 8.2% last fall, Piper Jaffray said.
Trailing in fourth place is Bose with 3.9%, followed by Sony (SNE) (2.6%) and JVC (0.8%), the investment bank said.
The percentage of teens planning to purchase headphones in the next six months increased to 60.4% in the fall survey, up from 56.3% in the spring and 57.6% in fall 2014.
The percentage of teens asking for headphones as gifts was flat at 1.6%, Piper Jaffray reported.

A survey released last week by the Consumer Electronics Association listed headphones and earbuds as the most popular tech items people planned to give this holiday season. Some 28% of respondents to a CEA survey said that they plan to buy headphones as gifts this season, followed by 27% for earbuds.
Other popular tech gift items this season include tablets (26%), portable Bluetooth speakers (25%), notebook or laptop computers (25%) and smartphones (24%).

Apple (AAPL) launched its bid to stay relevant in the music industry on Tuesday with the debut of Apple Music, a streaming music service built on its acquisition last year of Beats.Apple made the subscription service available to its millions of mobile device users through an update to the iOS 8 operating system about 11 a.m. EDT.Apple Music features an on-demand streaming music catalog of over 30 million tracks, playlists curated by experts, a live global radio station called Beats 1, and a social network linking fans and artists called Connect.The service costs $9.99 a month after a three-month trial period. A family plan supporting up to six listeners costs $14.99 a month.Apple created Apple Music to protect its iTunes franchise, which has been eroded by the popularity of streaming music services like Spotify and Internet radio services such as Pandora Media (P).When Apple unveiled Apple Music on June 8 at its Worldwide Developers Conference, the company described it as a revolutionary service for fans and artists. It combines all the ways consumers listen to music — downloads, streaming and Internet radio — in one app.Subscribers also can use Apple's Siri voice-activated personal assistant to access music. You can tell Siri: "Play me the best songs from 1994," "Play the best FKA Twigs song" or "What was the No. 1 song in February 2011?"Personal technology reviewer Walt Mossberg at Re/code gave Apple Music a tentative thumbs up, but said the app is "confusing."Apple Music is "uncharacteristically complicated by Apple standards, with everything from a global terrestrial radio station to numerous suggested playlists for different purposes in different places," Mossberg said. "And the company offers very little guidance on how to navigate its many features. It will take time to learn it. And that's not something you're going to want to do if all you're looking for is to lean back and listen."Where Apple Music might excel over rivals and help the recording industry is through music discovery. Through Beats 1 and curated playlists, Apple could expose music lovers to new artists.The first song played on Beats 1 was "City" by little-known U.K. rock band Spring King."Apple Music aims to solve the issue of poor music discovery," UBS analyst Steven Milunovich said in a research report this month.The success of Apple Music will prove whether Apple made the right decision in buying headphone maker Beats Electronics and its Beats Music streaming service for $3 billion. The deal, which closed last August, brought on board Beats co-founders and music industry luminaries Jimmy Iovine and Dr. Dre.Apple Music launched in over 100 countries and could provide a boost to subscription streaming music in the U.S., U.K., France and Japan, IHS analyst Dan Cryan told IBD."Apple is in a really interesting position to take on-demand music subscriptions to the mass market in countries like the U.S. and U.K.," Cryan said. The streaming market is still a relatively "green field" there because penetration rates are low compared with the overall population, he said.Apple has an edge over rivals by getting its music app distributed over millions of its smartphones, tablets and media players with a software update. "It's a huge advantage for them to be able to deploy at scale to that many people," he said.If 10% of iPhone users were to subscribe to Apple Music, it would rival market leader Spotify, which has more than 20 million paying subscribers, IHS said. Spotify also offers an advertising-supported free service tier, which Apple Music does not have.If just 1% of the iPhone installed base were to subscribe to Apple Music, it would generate the equivalent of 10% of the global digital album and single sales expected in 2016, IHS said.Apple Music is important to Apple "because music is fundamental to the mobile phone experience," Piper Jaffray analyst Gene Munster said in a note Tuesday. "By having a compelling music experience, the hope is Apple will sell more iPhones."But Munster said it's "highly unlikely" that Apple will match Spotify's subscriber count, which he pegged at 15 million.

Comcast, the nation's largest cable operator and Internet service provider, is sticking to its core businesses at a time when the media world is absorbing the seismic jolt of 21st Century Fox's gargantuan $80 billion offer for Time Warner.The cable giant's strategy is working. Comcast reported robust second-quarter earnings on July 22, fueled by a strong boost in its home Internet segment.Many industry players are trying to expand revenue streams in adventurous ways, such as Netflix (NFLX) deciding to create content, rather than simply deliver it through streaming and snail-mail. Apple (AAPL) stunned media and tech observers by acquiring the Dr. Dre-led headphones company, Beats, for $3 billion several weeks ago. Google (GOOGL) is moving aggressively into the potentially lucrative territory of "wearables" by marketing its invention Google Glass.Meanwhile, Comcast (CMCSA) has made a bet that size and scale matter and are efficient ways to reduce expenses. The approach has long been a hallmark of this financially savvy broadcasting and cable giant. Comcast made big headlines earlier this year when it offered $45.2 billion to acquire rival Time Warner Cable (TWC), the latest piece of its strategy to achieve growth by acquisitions. Regulators are reviewing the deal."What's remarkable about Comcast is that it once started out as a regional cable company — and now it has its name on Rockefeller Center," said Robert Thompson, a Syracuse University media professor who specializes in gauging the TV industry's impact on popular culture.By offering to buy Time Warner Cable, itself a huge player in the cable industry, the Philadelphia-based giant made a statement: We are quite content to build on its traditional strengths.Comcast is comfortable doing big deals to achieve growth. In 2011, it acquired NBCUniversal from General Electric and joined the heavyweights of network and cable TV broadcasting.There is no specific overlapping point in the U.S. where Comcast and Time Warner Cable compete with one another for customers. By the conclusion of 2013, Comcast and Time Warner Cable had roughly 21 million and 11 million Internet customers, respectively. As a combined entity, the pair would then command about two-thirds of the broadband cable market.Like every other large company in the media ecosystem, Comcast is trying to remain ahead of the curve today and, in the big picture, tomorrow and beyond.With so many entrepreneurs shaking the industry's foundation on a regular basis — remember both Facebook (FB) and Twitter (TWTR) are only a decade or so old — it's essential that players like Comcast plan for the next wave of change. For instance, look at how much social media has transformed the communications industry."Social media has definitely redefined the industry," said Anton Beyer, CEO of Up Capital Management Inc., a wealth management and financial planning firm in Granite Bay, Calif. "Comcast has to be paying close attention on how to adapt to these kinds of changes. The whole media world is up for grabs, and consolidation will be a big part of that story."Comcast's long-term strategy is evident. "Comcast is looking for synergies that will cut costs, rather than (exclusively) boost revenue, and cost synergies are much more reliable," said Paul Carroll, a principal in the Devil's Advocate Group, a technology-centric consulting firm."Comcast is also sticking to its core business, rather than trying something new so the additional size would likely lead to efficiencies, not complexity and inefficiency," Carroll said.Doing What It Does BestFor a company with Comcast's pedigree and clout, it makes sense to concentrate on what you can do well. "If I were running Comcast, I wouldn't be trying to figure out how to adapt my product to the new world or even figuring out what the new new world will be," said Sam Hill, co-author of "Radical Marketing: From Harvard to Harley, Lessons from Ten That Broke the Rules and Made It Big."Yes, the watchword in today's media industry is to branch out and tap new kinds of revenue streams. At the same time, Comcast has determined that the strategy of focusing on producing solid financial results is wise because it enables the company to have the resources to remain competitive for a long time."Today, media companies have to choose between being either hip, or profitable," said Charles Haddad, a professor at the Stony Brook University School of Journalism. "Few media companies are both. You don't get any hipper — or more relevant — than Twitter and its many copycats, but it has never earned a dime. Nor are its executives close to figuring that out. Ditto with Amazon."Despite its financial strength, this is a challenging time for Comcast. Its takeover attempt still requires the approval of the U.S. government. Comcast's lobbyists in Washington, D.C. must have an answer for the outcry by consumer groups who question whether such a monopoly might eventually harm customers since so much power would rest in the hands of one company, Comcast.Fighting Image ProblemPlus, Comcast must resolve its image problems with consumers. It hasn't always boasted a stellar reputation for service. To be fair, perhaps this is bound to be an occupational hazard for a cable company because the public loves to complain about it. To be sure, Comcast gets its share of negative publicity.For instance, Comcast recently had to live down what a MarketWatch headline proclaimed as "the Comcast call from hell." The fracas occurred when a Comcast customer tried by phone to terminate his account, only to encounter a rather overzealous customer-service representative. The Comcast employee basically wouldn't hear of it and kept the customer on the phone for a much longer than was necessary. http://blogs.marketwatch.com/themargin/2014/07/15/have-you-ever-had-a-cancellation-asad-as-this-comcast-experience/Much of Comcast's future rests on whether the government will approve its takeover of Time Warner Cable. This proposed deal enables Comcast to continue to grow by taking advantage of its core businesses and providing for the long term."Comcast is aiming at a sweet spot that should stay sweet for at least a decade," Carroll pointed out. "That sweet spot is the connection to the Internet, that everyone these days treats as being as basic as having electricity and water. Cable is easily the fastest way to connect to the Internet — much faster than DSL and wireless — so those who own cable have a big advantage."
